0.text:
Translator: Mohammed Basheer
Reviewer: Denise RQ

5.text:
Today I want to talk with you
about a subject

7.text:
that many people have been talking
about for a very long time.

14.text:
Success means different things
to different people,

17.text:
but what is success might mean to me
is different than what it may mean to you.

22.text: And what it may mean to you,

24.text:
is different than what it means
to a kindergartner

27.text:
who is just trying to get a star
on his homework assignment.

33.text:
who has been trying
to get her five kids in bed be 9pm.

37.text: Or maybe even a corporate executive

40.text:
who's been working for his
or her corporation for 20-plus years,

44.text:
and only wants to become
the CEO of their organization.

51.text:
we have so many different definitions
of this word success,

55.text:
but the greatest definition
I can give you today is this,

64.text: It's about being who you want to be,

67.text: doing what you want to do,

69.text: going where you want to go.

71.text: Because when it comes to your life,

74.text: you are the boss, and you have a choice.

78.text: In fact, you are who you are today

81.text:
because of all the choices
that you've made in your entire life.

87.text:
But as we are growing up
we have a lot of people

90.text:
who try to tell us
how to make these choices;

92.text:
our parents, our teachers, our bosses,
our friends, even our neighbors.

98.text: They try to tell us how to live our lives,

100.text: what we should do, where we should go,

102.text: how we should walk, how we should talk.

105.text: But my question for you is this,

108.text:
"If you're trying to be
what other people want you to be,

116.text:
So the key to success is to stop
conforming to other people expectations,

121.text:
and start performing
to your own level of expectations.

126.text:
Is to know that what you want
will eventually come to fruition,

130.text: as long as you believe it.

132.text: You see, you have to have faith,

134.text:
and faith is knowing that what you want
will eventually come to fruition

139.text: as long as you believe it.

141.text: And if you feed your faith,

142.text:
you will find often times
that your fears will starve to death,

146.text: because if you believe in yourself,

149.text:
everyone else in the world
will believe in you.

154.text:
Fortunately, for a long time,
I didn't quite believe in myself.

158.text: Actually, I used to be the kind of person

161.text:
that mothers would often
warn their daughters about,

164.text: and fathers would tell their sons,

166.text:
"If you keep doing
what Daniel Ally is doing,

168.text:
you are going to end up
where Daniel Ally is going."

171.text:
They had some credence
to what they were saying,

175.text:
your reputation really is
your best advertisement.

178.text: I really didn't have a good reputation,

181.text:
because I was living
so far below my potential,

184.text:
I was actually living
in my mother's basement.

188.text:
By the age of 21,
I'd worked over 40 different jobs.

192.text:
I got fired from more jobs
than more people had.

196.text:
In high school,
I graduated second to last,

199.text: the last guy; well, he was in jail.

203.text:
I was on drugs for eight years,
and I was confused.

206.text: I was broke, busted, and disgusted,

209.text: and I knew that I wanted to change;

212.text: the only problem was I didn't know how.

216.text:
Can I see a show of hands
if you've ever been in a situation

219.text:
where you wanted to change,
but you just didn't know what to do?

224.text: Well, we all have been there,

227.text: maybe we are there right now.

229.text:
I discovered there are only three ways
that I can make a change in my life.

233.text:
Three ideas I wanted
to share with you today

235.text:
that can absolutely revolutionize
your life from today.

239.text:
I know these steps work
because I've been able to do them myself.

243.text:
By the age of 24,
I became a self-made millionaire.

246.text:
I have been able to write three books
and travel to dozens of countries.

251.text:
I now reach millions
of people with my work.

254.text:
I believe that these three key principles
can change your life,

257.text: no matter how do you define success

259.text:
whether you want to live to age 100
or even have a dozen kids,

263.text:
or just have a house on the mountaintop
somewhere no one knows about.

268.text:
These three key principles will help you
to realize the success in your life.

273.text: The first one is to read more books.

277.text:
All the books in the world can help us
to solve all the problems in the world.

282.text:
But the truth is that we don't have
to read all the books in the world,

286.text:
because we don't have
all the problems in the world,

289.text:
but we do have to read the books
that help us to solve our problems.

293.text:
So, for instance, if you wanted
to learn about money,

296.text:
you better be reading books
that talk about money.

300.text:
Or if you wanted to learn
how to manage your relationships,

303.text:
or to become a better communicator,
there are a lot of books on that.

308.text:
is there are libraries that are paved
with gold, and library cards are free.

313.text:
Books are the tools
that release the heavens of your mind.

321.text:
If you want to succeed,
you have to read.

324.text:
Most people in the world
read about one book every single year,

328.text:
that book, I would suppose,
would be Facebook.

333.text:
And before people even get up
and do their things,

336.text:
before they drink their coffee
or read their paper, they read Facebook.

340.text:
But the truth is that if you study
miscellaneous things,

347.text:
What do you study,
and where is it taking you?

351.text:
A lot of people come up to me,
and they say,

353.text:
"Daniel, I don't really have time to read.
I have kids, I have work, I am student.

358.text:
I already have so many textbooks,
I am doing so many things, I am too busy."

363.text: But if you don't have 10 minutes a day,

365.text:
you're basically saying
you don't have a life.

367.text: We all have time to read,

369.text: we all have time to pick up a good book

371.text:
and read for ourselves
so that we can learn.

373.text:
Look! If you read 10 minutes a day,
for 30 straight days,

378.text: that is one book a month.

379.text:
One book a month, in 12 months,
is 12 books a year.

383.text:
You can do in one year
what most people do in five years.

389.text: We all have time to read.

393.text:
and the only way
you can succeed is if you read.

398.text:
is about getting around
the best individuals you can.

402.text: We're the sum total of five people

405.text:
in which we surround ourselves
with the most.

407.text:
We earn the same income,
we go to the same places,

410.text:
we do the same things,
we think the same thoughts.

412.text:
And if you were to look
at your five closest friends,

415.text:
you've got to ask yourself
this one question,

418.text:
"Who are my leaders,
and where are they taking me?"

424.text:
"Are my leaders taking me
to the place I'd most likely want to be?"

430.text:
If the answer is no,
then you need new leaders.

433.text:
You need people who are inspiring,
people that can help you,

436.text:
lift you up to the goals that transcend
your own possibility and your thinking.

442.text: You have to realize your goals,

444.text:
and you can only do that
by getting around the right people.

447.text:
Many of us have what I like
to call "defult friends".

450.text:
Default friends are basically people
that we see around the neighborhood,

455.text:
people at the grocery store, the gym,
the mall, at church, at work,

461.text:
These are people
that we naturally befriend

463.text:
as we start to gain
their trust and acceptance.

466.text:
And what tends to happen is,
if you are a highly ambitious person,

471.text: and you have really high goals,

473.text:
a lot of these people
can help you reach your goals.

477.text:
So you have to look outside,
you have to search for people.

482.text:
I had a friend, his name was John,
and he was actually a plumber,

485.text:
and his father and him
had a pretty successful business,

488.text: at least it seemed like it.

490.text:
"I want to start a business,
what exactly do you think I should do?"

494.text: John pulled me to the corner and said,

496.text:
"Daniel, I don't think
you want to start a business,

499.text:
98% of businesses fail
within the first three years."

504.text:
Then he proceeded to tell me about
all the reasons why I couldn't do it,

509.text:
He told me how was so hard
working over 100 hours a week,

513.text: how hard it was to manage payroll,

515.text:
and why the recession was holding him back
from getting more clients.

520.text:
As he told me this, I became
a little discouraged, a little dejected,

524.text: and I went home, and I thought about it.

526.text:
When I get to my journal,
I usually reflect,

529.text:
and I wrote down in my journal,
"The 98% of statistics are made up."

538.text:
You have to realize that no one's opinion
of you can become your reality.

545.text:
And in order to change your reality,
you've to change your mentality

549.text: and the people you surround yourself with.

551.text:
You have to get yourself
around people who can help you,

554.text:
people that are smarter than you,
people who have gone further than you;

557.text:
people who know what you need to do
to get to that next level.

561.text:
The truth is that the people
that you are looking for

564.text:
are also looking for you,
but you have to find them.

568.text:
Sometimes, we surround ourselves
with strangers and family members

573.text:
who tell us what we can't do,
they limit us.

575.text: A lot of people have the right intentions,

578.text:
but often times,
they provide the wrong directions.

582.text:
In other words, they want to help us,
but they just don't know how.

586.text: So get around people who can.

588.text:
A lot of people ask me,
"Daniel, how do you find these people?"

592.text:
If you flow step one,
which is to read more books,

595.text:
you'll find that in the back of the book
there is the "About the Author" section.

599.text:
What I used to do
is I used to reach out to the authors.

602.text: Thankfully, we live in a new millennium

604.text:
which allows us to get on
their social media, their websites,

607.text:
and so we can have
a conversation with them.

609.text:
We can change by actually understanding
what it is that they teach.

614.text:
And if we ask enough questions,
we can make great progress in our life.

618.text:
Remember that people you're looking for
are also looking for you,

622.text: so get yourself around those people.

624.text:
My last and final suggestion
is to set higher goals,

629.text:
they help you to become
more of who you are.

632.text: And in this enormity of conformity,

634.text:
so many people don't know
how to set goals,

637.text: they get confused about the process.

640.text:
A lot of people use
New Year's resolutions,

644.text:
but the problem
with New Year's resolutions

646.text:
is that the person often
tries to do too much, too fast.

650.text: Let's say Doug wants to stop smoking.

658.text:
He hasn't created a plan of action
to achieve his goals,

665.text:
Bucket list is something else
that people do,

668.text:
and usually, when someone
creates a bucket list,

670.text: they're giving themselves too much time.

672.text:
There is no urgency, and most of the time,
they don't write their goals down.

679.text: Well, I am glad you asked.

680.text:
What I do suggest for you
is to write your goals down.

683.text:
I believe that a dull pencil
is better than a sharp mind,

687.text:
and to impress your subconscious mind,
you have to write your goals down,

691.text:
so that you can hold this steadfastly
to who you are.

694.text:
I have this method
I teach all around the world,

700.text:
is you select one overarching goal
that you would like to accomplish,

704.text:
analyze 20 ideas
correspond with that particular goal.

708.text:
Let's say, for instance,
you wanted to be a better public speaker.

713.text: What are some things you can do?

715.text:
Well, you could watch TED talks,
like you are now,

717.text:
you could practice your speech,
look in the mirror to challenge yourself,

722.text: you could read the dictionary every day.

724.text:
There are so many things you can do,
but could I come up with 20 ideas?

728.text:
The answer is, "Yes,
I can come up with a 100 if wanted to."

732.text:
Imagine if you did this
in every area in your life:

735.text:
financially, for promotions,
for your family,

739.text: and you wrote your goals on every day.

742.text:
You would be able to accomplish
so many things in your life.

745.text:
We have everything we need
in order to succeed,

748.text:
but we have to take the things we have
to get more of the things that we want;

752.text:
from the cars that we drive,
to the clothes that we wear,

755.text:
to the food that we eat,
and the people that we meet.

758.text:
In this depository of diversity, we have
everything we need in order to succeed,

769.text:
you will find that everyone in the world
will believe in you.

772.text: And you also have to think big.

774.text:
When you think big,
you will do big, and you will win big.

777.text:
Well, B-I-G is actually is the 3 ideas
that I want to share with you today:

780.text: B -- the books that you read,

782.text: I -- the individuals that you meet,

784.text:
and G -- the goals
that you set for yourself.

787.text:
Books, individuals, and goals:
that's all you need to accomplish success,

792.text:
because when you think big,
you will do big,

794.text: and you will win big, my friends.
